SENT.plain: A 36-year-old man with a history of migraine without aura, presented with recurrent bouts of severe headache, perception of flashing lights in both visual fields, and transient bilateral neurological deficits
In view of his history, migraine with aura was considered
Ancillary investigations showed bilateral extracranial internal carotid artery dissection

This case illustrates that when attacks of severe headache with scotomata and transient bilateral neurological deficits occur in a patient with a history of migraine, the diagnosis of carotid artery dissection should be considered, especially when the pattern of headache is different or when some clinical characteristics have not been experienced previously
